For kicks and giggles:
For up:
v^2 = u^2 + 2as (find s)
0 = 900 - 2 x 10s
s =-900/-20 =45 m

v = u + at (find t)
0 = 30 - 10t
t = - 30/-10 = 3s

For down:
v^2 = u^2 +2as (find v)
v^2 = 0 +2 x 10 x 45 =900
v= 30 m/s

v = u +at (find t)
30 = 0 +10t
t = 3s

Alternatively, using common sense: an object subject to no acceleration, travelling at 30m/s would travel 90 m in 3 s. An object that decelerates under gravity (constant rate) from 30m/s to zero over 3s travels at an average of 15 m/s, so will cover half the distance of the 30m/s object = 90m/2 = 45m.

I really really wish you would have used 9.8 instead of 10. My physics book says that we'll generally always use 2 sig figs, even if it ends in a zero. So 10 would be two sig figs, with or without the decimal, we still consider it as two. So 9.8 and 10 are the same sig figs, but totally different values. For myself personally I found it harder to follow along with the 10's because it didn't compare the same with every single problem I have to figure out for homework, which is why I'm watching this. I'm having such a hard time figuring out which equations to use to figure out these kinds of problems. When the constants are different, it just becomes one more thing I have to compensate for mentally before coming to an understanding of what's going on. :/ Just my thoughts, in the end I'm still watching tho xD

In a related thing, if you can jump 1 meter in the air on earth, how high could you jump on the moon?  Using d=1/2at^2, I have both d and t and unknown.  We know that a=9.82m/s^2 on earth and 1.62m/s^2 on the moon.  How do we convert this formula into force when you jump so we can assume it is the same on earth and the moon.  Then we know how high we can jump.

When you really think about it, a particle is merely a kink in a zipper, a spot where there is one too many left clips per right clip. And an anti particle to this one is a kink in the zipper such that there is one too many right clips per left clip. And if somehow you were able to move these particles together, they vanish.
Which likely means that the quark anti quark pairs that form in a vacuum are just kinks in the fabric of the universe.

Update: Whooooo! Thank you so much - I am covering free fall this week in class and was thrilled to see this video pop up in my list of options with real captions!

As a physics teacher, I love these videos and would love to use them in my classes, but the auto-captions that they currently have do not meet ADA standards for my Deaf and Hard of Hearing students. YouTube makes it pretty easy to go through and edit the captions for grammar and accuracy (ie adding punctuation and correcting any words that did not transcribe properly). I know many of your videos are on DCMP (described and captioned media program) with full and proper captions, would love to see that for this series of physics videos as well!

When you said, jumping in a pool and calculating the decceleration was easy, I immediately loudly opposed that idea.
With the typical oversimplification of most physics BASE lessons, yes, it seems easy at the basic level.
Here we ignore so many real-life factors that even a failed physics student like me can see the problems for an exact measurement cropping up right, left, and center.
For a basic ball-park figure, yes, the base calculations will give a very good approximation to several decimals exactness, possibly.
But once you start figuring in some truely significant variables this problem immediately jumps from trivial to doctorate level of difficulty.

Due to the change of resistance of air to water, the effect of buoyancy of air in your body in comparisson to the water changes at non-trivial levels.
Ask any SCUBA diver to take down an empty balloon and fill it underwater at a specific depth, then carry it upwards during surfacing. The buoyancy of the expanding air is enormous.
The same applies to your lungs depending on where you take your last gasp of breath before submerging.

I know that air is simply a very very dry liquid when it comes to fluid dynamics.
Buuuut: the air in your lungs get's compressed when you dive into water.
Thus the depth of the water you reach changes your decceleration due to increased compression of air, thus lowered buoyancy.
I'd wager a bet that calculating the EXACT time for your decceleration in the water, plus the EXACT distance you SHOULD reach below the surface level of the water becomes INSANELY complicated when you factor in all relevant and significant variables. I'd definitely assume that this is not trivial, but truely worthy of a dissertation level problem.
Leaving your mistakes in is a brilliant choice.

It might be interesting to mention that the mass of the falling object does not intervene anywhere in the equation, because it is so counter intuitive for people who think heavier objects will fall faster. Cue in some footage from Apollo 15 when David Scott dropped a hammer and a feather on the moon. And it will help you make a segue the F=ma later to show that mass does play a part in how much force your object will have at the bottom. I feel like it’s always important to show how our intuition can deceive us and how science helps us see what’s really happening.

Have a question, isn't the air resistance proportional to the square of the speed? I don't think this would affect the overall results in that it would fall slower. During the Apollo 15 mission to the moon, Astronaut Dave Scott did a variation on what you where showing in this video. If a hammer and a feather were dropped at the same time, would they hit the surface of the Moon at the same time? Less time up or down?
With the bottle flipping trick it must be less time down.
Why? Well the physics she just went though applies to the center of mass. Since the water starts in the bottom of the bottle and ends with the water all over the place, the base will hit the table BEFORE the CoM is finishes falling.
Ergo - Since the CoM takes the same amount of time to fall, the bottle takes less.

Takes longer to come down then go up. So next question would be can shapes change this?

Personally I think it wise to teach youngsters to “measure first and >>then analyze/read/data mine/study<< To say that “all motion is understood” and ‘these are the formulas’ …. umm, isn’t that backwards ? Some1 had to measure first and ask later !!! To “notice first and measure later IS the same sentence.” If thou was underwater >> Do those same laws uphold ? =rhetorical . In other words, i see all too often that parents think their children are “not as smart” , that they need to be babied, they’re not ‘ready for it yet’ …. Then when time beholds,, the children leap off from where they were taught/explained…. In other words, some kids start their lives from nursery rhymes, some from Newtonian physics and some from Pandas LIDAR and sensor data. Who is right ehhhhh ?
Ditch the right er wrong, right !!??
I remember a time when I was bored and wanted to follow along to the original book Newton did on optics,, something like 10 pages in,, I kept screaming at the page >> Bro , can I please just Amazon you a laser pointer !! I really appreciate you, and alll u have done for history, but “its red !! “ You really should check it out !! Look at the mathematical relationships. You can see them !!!! Inside and outside ,,, wow, that Newton dude sat there with a candle, with the slightest glimpse. The light wouldn’t go much farther than multiple rooms. In other words >> I dunno if you have tried to dig a swimming pool with a shovel, , , but woa that will take you a while !!! Its not that he was lacking, but we do the best with what we got.
in other words ;
- physics of the future -
1.) Measure first / Notice Prior
2.) What are we looking at
3.) Characterize it
4.) Figure its bounds
5.) Study it. ALL OF IT .
6.) Explain its exploitations to other humans
7.) Hope you not Oppie
8.) # 5 - 7 are a joke and a victory lap, Aka don’t feed chocolate cake to the one who already ate all the chocolate cake.
9.) Beer and physics are only okay “not holidays, on not lockdown, in not lab”

lol the diving board

16:20 When she use d=at²/2, she is thinking about the phenomenon backwards in time. That's why she get a positive acceleration. Which doesn't make sense at first because you're decelerating.
If we take the other way in time we get: right before entering the pool, she had Vo=10 m/s. Therefore ∆y= Vo•t+a•t²/2, meaning 2.5 = 10•t+a•t²/2.
The time it takes is 0.5s so 2.5=5+a/8,
a= - 20 m/s². Which is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction.

If the average acceleration is 10m/s square, then after 1 sec , by logic, it traveled 10m
After 2 seconds..
2sec square = 4
10m/4sec after 2 seconds.
So 5m after 2 sec.
This series is amazing.

Second^2 means second x second
10 m/sec. × sec.
- after 1 second
1 second x 1 second =1
-10 m/1sec.= 10m

So after 1 second it should be 10m further.

After 2 seconds..
2 seconds x 2 seconds = 4 seconds
10m/4 seconds
We want to know " after 2 seconds "
So ... If its 10m for 4 seconds..
Its 5m for 2 seconds.
